properties.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued February 29 at 2:21PM CST by NWS Huntsville AL
properties.description:
A series of storm systems will traverse the Tennessee Valley for
the first half of the upcoming work week, bringing widespread
rainfall amounts of 4 to 5 inches for portions of the area. Given
our wet start to 2020, this will pose a significant flooding
threat because soils are so saturated, even with the drier weather
in the past few days. Though rain is in the forecast beginning
Sunday night, rain chances will linger through Thursday, the most
significant rainfall amounts will occur Wednesday and Thursday.
There continues to be some uncertainty with the timeframe as
models come into better timing agreements, so further adjustments
are likely warranted in the next day or two. Some flash flooding
is likely, though the overall threat will continue to be river
flooding and any associated impacts from that (flooded roadways,
etc.).

Rainfall during the month of January was above normal for the
entire forecast area in Northern Alabama and Southern Middle TN,
with the highest rainfall occurring along and west of Interstate
65. In these locations, rainfall was between 3 and 5 inches above
normal, with several spots ranging between 5 and 8 inches above
normal for the month. February was no different, as we saw last
year. Above normal rainfall continued, and even increased for
February 2020, with many locations tallying between 5 and 8
inches above normal once again. As of today, numerous sites across
the forecast area have measured well over a foot of rainfall for
the month, with several sites approaching 15+ inches for February
2020.

If the forecast verifies this week with the rainfall expected
(4-5", with isolated higher amounts), widespread river flooding
will occur. Initially, smaller creeks and streams will become
overwhelmed and overflow their banks, eventually flowing into
larger creek and river tributaries of the Tennessee River by
midweek. This would include the Flint River, Paint Rock River, Elk
River, and Big Nance Creek in Northern Alabama and Southern Middle
Tennessee. Then, those floodwaters will flow into the Tennessee
River, and we'll have lingering effects from that through the
upcoming weekend, most likely. In addition to any rainfall that
occurs this upcoming week, the Tennessee Valley Authority is
already spilling water downstream to essentially "make room" for
the expected rainfall totals next week, and they will do their
best to manage the potential flooding situation along the
mainstem of the Tennessee River as possible.

Please stay tuned for further forecast updates over the coming
days. The rainfall forecast will continue to be updated and
adjusted as model guidance comes into better agreement over the
next 24-48 hours. Have a plan in place now! Know what to do when
and if a Flood Warning is issued for your location! Move to higher
ground immediately, and remember, when traveling, TURN AROUND,
DON'T DROWN! Finding alternate routes to a flooded roadway may
save your life!

NWSheadline: Several Rounds of Heavy Rainfall Expected from Early Monday through Thursday Next Week, Leading to More Flooding
